abstract.p: Robert Hercz brief assessments of some World Wide Web sites on wine (S)

block.p: THE World Wide Web site of the Wine Spectator (www.winespectator.com) is an impressive starting point for on-line wine resources. The magazine's text is only one issue behind the newsstand, and there is a free searchable database of 15,000 reviews, with tasting notes and ratings, covering the previous two years. There is a Wine Basics section with essays on tasting and varietals, country-by-country descriptions of wines and more.

Folksy and friendly, Robin Garr's Wine Lovers' Page (www.wine-lovers-page.com) includes a huge volume of resources, highlighted by Mr. Garr's ''Quick Wine-Tasting Course,'' a collection of articles he wrote for The Louisville (Ky.) Courier-Journal. There are also tasting forms, a glossary, vintage charts and bulletin boards for discussions.

Other magazines worth visiting on the Web include Smart Wine Online (smartwine.com) and Wine Enthusiast (www.winemag.com). All sites, of course, have links to other sites, increasing the chances of finding pleasant surprises like Corkscrew.Com (www.corkscrew.com), devoted to a San Francisco Bay Area couple's 20-year passion for collecting corkscrews.
